emerging_technologies.name: AI-Driven Software Development Lifecycle
emerging_technologies.description: AI tools evolve to manage the entire software development process from design to deployment, optimizing workflows, predicting issues, and automating routine tasks.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Reduces human error, speeds up development cycles, potentially reduces entry barriers for new developers, but might lead to job displacement in traditional coding roles.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: High adoption due to productivity gains, but requires cultural shift in software development practices and regulatory oversight to ensure ethical AI use.

emerging_technologies.name: Neuralink-Style Brain Interfaces
emerging_technologies.description: Non-invasive brain-computer interfaces that allow for control of devices, enhanced learning, and direct human-to-human communication.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Could revolutionize how we interact with technology, improve quality of life for those with disabilities, but raises ethical concerns about privacy, consent, and cognitive liberty.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Initial adoption will be niche, focusing on medical applications, with wider consumer adoption potentially hindered by ethical and privacy concerns.

emerging_technologies.name: Fully Autonomous Urban Transport
emerging_technologies.description: Urban transport systems where vehicles are completely autonomous, integrating with smart city infrastructures for optimized traffic flow.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Reduction in traffic accidents, improved urban mobility, but also potential job losses in driving professions and issues with data privacy.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: Requires robust regulatory frameworks, public trust in autonomous systems, and significant infrastructure investment.

emerging_technologies.name: Space Solar Power
emerging_technologies.description: Satellites in space collect solar energy and beam it back to Earth as microwave or laser energy for widespread, clean energy distribution.
emerging_technologies.societal_implications: Offers a sustainable energy solution, reducing reliance on fossil fuels, but involves complex international cooperation and space law considerations.
emerging_technologies.adoption_factors: High initial cost, technological challenges, and geopolitical considerations might slow adoption.

mainstream_technologies.name: AI Coding Assistants
mainstream_technologies.description: AI tools that not only suggest code but also help in debugging, understanding project context, and managing version control.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Widely adopted in tech industries, becoming standard tools in development environments.

mainstream_technologies.name: Blockchain for Digital Identity
mainstream_technologies.description: Decentralized identity systems using blockchain technology to ensure privacy and security in digital interactions.
mainstream_technologies.adoption_status: Becoming standard in sectors like finance, healthcare, and government services for secure identity verification.

epoch_themes.description: A shift towards systems and technologies that operate with minimal human intervention, enhancing efficiency and reducing human error.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Changes in workforce dynamics, redefinition of job roles, and new ethical considerations for autonomous decision-making.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Increased focus on AI ethics, regulations for autonomous systems, and integration into everyday life.

epoch_themes.description: Technologies aimed at enhancing human capabilities, either physically or cognitively, through interfaces with technology.
epoch_themes.societal_impact: Potential for significant improvements in health, education, and human interaction, alongside concerns over inequality, privacy, and identity.
epoch_themes.global_trends: Growth in neurotech industry, ethical debates on enhancement, and regulatory frameworks for human augmentation.
